tn.text: This second warning is longer and more detailed and includes chapters 3 and 4. The writer begins by showing that Christ is better than his servant Moses.

Here "brothers" refer to fellow Christians, including both men and women. AT: "holy brothers and sisters" or "my holy fellow believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: you share in a heavenly calling
tn.text: Here "heavenly" represents God. AT: "God has called us together"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here this term means someone who has been sent. In this passage, it does not refer to any of the twelve apostles. AT: "the one who was sent"
This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "confession" is expressed as the verb "confess." AT: "whom we confess" or "in whom we believe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The Hebrew people to whom God revealed himself are spoken of as if they were a literal house. AT: "to all of God's people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God has considered Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
God's acts of creating the world are spoken of as if he had built a house. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: every house is built by someone
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "every house has someone who built it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This phrase starts a comparison between Moses and Christ. This phrase can be left out of your translation, if necessary.

The Hebrew people to whom God revealed himself are spoken of as if they were a literal house. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:heb:03:01|3:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He was a testimony about the things
tn.text: This phrase probably refers to all of Moses' work. AT: "Moses' life and work pointed to the things"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: were to be spoken of in the future
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Jesus would say in the future" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an important title for Jesus, the Son of God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This speaks about God's people as if they were a literal house. AT: "who rules over God's people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This speaks of God's people as if they are a literal house. AT: "We are God's people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: if we hold fast to our courage and to our proud confidence
tn.text: Here "courage" and "proud confidence" are abstract and can be stated as verbs. AT: "if we continue to be courageous and joyfully expect God to do what he has promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

The warning here is a reminder that the Israelites' unbelief kept almost all of them from entering into the land that God had promised them. Their unbelief was well illustrated in Exodus [[:en:bible:notes:exo:17:01|17:1-7]], when they complained against Moses and doubted that God was with them.
This quotation comes from  the Old Testament in the book of Psalms.
God's commands to Israel are spoken of as if he had given them in an audible voice. AT: "if you hear God speaking"  "(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Stubbornness is spoken of as if it were a heart that had been physically hardened. AT: "do not be stubborn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: as in the rebellion, in the time of testing in the wilderness
tn.text: Here "rebellion" and "tested" can be stated as verbs. AT: "like when your ancestors rebelled against God and tested him in the wilderness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This quotation is from the Psalms.
Here "your" is plural and refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "me" refers to God.
"40 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"I was angry" or "I was greatly unhappy"

tn.ref: They are always being led astray in their hearts
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They are always going astray in their hearts" or "Their hearts are always going astray" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: They are always being led astray in their hearts
tn.text: People who are unfaithful to God are spoken of as if someone were leading them off the right path to follow. AT: "They always refuse to follow me" or "They will not do what I command" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "hearts" refers to their minds or desires. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They have not known my ways
tn.text: This speaks of a manner of conducting one's life as if it were a way or a path. AT: "They do not understand how I wanted them to conduct their lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: They will never enter my rest
tn.text: The peace and security provided by God are spoken of as if they were rest that he can give, and as if they were a place to which people could go. AT: "They will never enter the place of rest" or "I will never allow them to experience my blessings of rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here this refers to fellow Christians including males and females. AT: "brothers and sisters" or "fellow believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: there will not be anyone with an evil heart of unbelief
tn.text: The heart is spoken of here as if it were a person's mind, the center of a person's will and motivation. AT: "none of you stop believing in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a heart that turns away from the living God
tn.text: The heart of a person is spoken of as if it were the entire person, who could abandon the right path to follow. AT: "and you stop obeying the living God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the true God who is really alive"

tn.ref: as long as it is called "today"
tn.text: "while there is still opportunity"

tn.ref: no one among you will be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the deceitfulness of sin does not harden any of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: no one among you will be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin
tn.text: Being stubborn is spoken of as being hard or having a hard heart. The hardness is a result of being deceived by sin. This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "deceitfulness" is expressed as the verb "deceive." AT: "no one among you will be deceived by sin and become stubborn" or "you do not sin, deceiving yourselves so that you become stubborn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This continues the  quotation from the same psalm that was also quoted in [[:en:bible:notes:heb:03:07|3:7]].
Here "we" refers to both the writer and the readers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: if we firmly hold to our confidence in him
tn.text: "if we continue to confidently trust in him"
"from when we first begin to believe in him"
This is a polite way of referring to when a person dies. AT: "until we die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the writer wrote" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

God's commands to Israel are spoken of as if he had given them in an audible voice. AT: "if you hear God speaking." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:heb:03:07|3:7-8]]. "(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here "rebellion" can be stated as a verb. AT: "like when your ancestors rebelled against God." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:heb:03:07|3:7-8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The word "they" refers to the disobedient Israelites, and "we" refers to the author and readers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: Who was it who heard God and rebelled? Was it not all those who came out of Egypt through Moses?
tn.text: The author uses questions to teach his readers. These two questions can be joined as one statement, if needed. AT: "All those who came out of Egypt with Moses heard God, yet they still rebelled." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: With whom was he angry for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose dead bodies fell in the wilderness?
tn.text: The author uses questions to teach his readers. These two questions can be joined as one statement, if needed. AT: "God was angry for forty years with those who sinned and let them die in the wilderness." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"40 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: To whom did he swear that they would not enter his rest, if it was not to those who disobeyed him?
tn.text: The author uses this question to teach his readers. AT: "And it was to those who disobeyed that he swore that he would not let them enter his rest." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: they would not enter his rest
tn.text: The peace and security provided by God are spoken of as if they were rest that he can give, and as if they were a place to which people could go. AT: "they would not enter the place of rest" or "they would not experience his blessings of rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "unbelief" can be stated in terms of the verb "trust." AT: "because they did not trust him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
